In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    # Lowercase the string
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscore
    col = replace(col, r"\s|-|_" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```

This function takes a string `col` as input and returns the cleaned column name in lowercase with any leading or trailing whitespaces removed and spaces/hyphens replaced with underscores.

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

This function is not specific to a particular data structure (like `DataFrame` in DataFrames.jl) and can be used for any string that needs to have its column name cleaned in the described manner. If you are working with `DataFrames`, you might want to use this function within more complex operations on your dataset.
